Byline: The Register-Guard

Arnold Duerst

COTTAGE GROVE - The funeral will be April 22 for Arnold Duerst of Cottage Grove, who died April 17 of age-related causes. He was 104.

Duerst was born March 23, 1898, in Waukon, Iowa, to Mathias and Louisa Britt Duerst. His parents had emigrated from Switzerland.

He married Violet Robbins in Cottage Grove on March 1, 1920. She died June 20, 1993.

Duerst's family moved to Oregon in 1908 and settled in Cottage Grove, where he attended Blue Mountain School. He left school and began working in the woods when he was 16.

He worked as a contract logger with a team of 1,600-pound horses that Duerst said could pull anything. He also worked in several local mills. He produced most of his families food by farming and raising cattle and pigs.

His Cottage Grove home was a quarter-mile from where he lived as a boy. Duerst lived in his home until December 2001, when he moved to Eugene Rehabilitation & Specialty Care. He was recently honored as their resident of the month.

Duerst was featured in a Register-Guard article on March 24, 2002.

He enjoyed music, singing, yodeling and dancing, and he played the harmonica at dances in his later years. Duerst especially enjoyed being a father and spending time with his family.

Survivors include two sons, Everett and Roy, both of Cottage Grove; two daughters, Betty Hand of Cottage Grove and Evelyn Cline of Oakridge; his 103-year-old sister, Louise Cowing of Tacoma; and numerous grandchildren, great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren. A son, Clarence, died in 1955.

Visitation will be held from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. Sunday at Smith-Lund-Mills Funeral Chapel in Cottage Grove. Monday's service will be at 1 p.m. at the funeral home. Burial will be at Brumbaugh Cemetery in Cottage Grove.

Minnie Robertson

The funeral will be April 23 for Minnie E. Robertson of Portland, formerly of Eugene, who died April 28 of Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases. She was 85.

Robertson was born Aug. 11, 1916, in Palmer, Kan., to Oscar and Margaret Bernard McAtee. She married Andrew Robertson in Vancouver, Wash., on Jan. 20, 1937. He died Dec. 16, 1986.

She graduated from Oakridge High School. Robertson was a homemaker and enjoyed gardening, knitting and crocheting. She moved from Oakridge to Eugene, where she lived for 53 years before moving to Portland 1 1/2 years ago.

Survivors include two sons, Jim of Beaufort, S.C., and David of Long Beach, Calif.; a daughter, Eileen Johnson of Portland; a brother LeRoy McAtee of Oakridge; a sister, Hazel Tiller of Oakridge; six grandchildren; and four great-grand- children.

Tuesday's service will be at 11 a.m. at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Eugene. Burial will be at 1 p.m. Tuesday at Rest-Haven Memorial Park in Eugene. Musgrove Family Mortuary in Eugene is in charge of arrangements.

Betty Purdy

SPRINGFIELD - Betty Irene Purdy of Springfield died April 17 of cancer. She was 79.

Purdy was born March 29, 1923, in Long Beach, Calif., to Grady and Ruth Sala Campbell.

During World War II, she worked in the shipyards in San Diego. She moved to the Eugene-Springfield area in 1945.

Purdy was a homemaker and artist. She enjoyed gardening and had a beautiful singing voice.

Survivors include a daughter, Linda Dannen of Springfield; two sons, Scott and Walter, both of Springfield; a sister, Helen Carlson of Long Beach, Calif.; and two grandchildren.

No service is planned. In- urnment will be at Springfield Memorial Gardens. Chapel of Memories Funeral Home in Eugene is in charge of arrangements.

Joyce Powers

COTTAGE GROVE - The funeral will be April 23 for Joyce M. Powers of Cottage Grove, who died April 18 of age-related causes. She was 81.

Powers was born Nov. 2, 1920, in Ralls, Texas, to William and Cynthia Witcher Carter. She married Raymond Powers in Juarez, Mexico, on Dec. 12, 1938.

She moved to Cottage Grove in 1948 and worked as a nurse's aide at Cottage Grove Hospital for 15 years before retiring. She was a Portland Trail Blazers fan and enjoyed reading and word games. Powers was a member of the Riding Club, the Ladies of the Moose and the Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary, all of Cottage Grove.

Survivors include a son, Bob of Creswell; a daughter, Brenda Nelson of Cottage Grove; four grandchildren; and one great-grandchild. A son, Jerry, died in 1978.

Visitation will be from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. Sunday and 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. and 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. Monday at Smith-Lund-Mills Funeral Chapel in Cottage Grove. Tuesday's service will be at 2 p.m., also at the funeral chapel. Burial will be at Fir Grove Cemetery in Cottage Grove.

Norma Thompson

The funeral will be today, April 20, for Norma Jean Thompson of Bend, formerly of Eugene, who died April 15 of cancer. She was 63.

Thompson was born April 11, 1939, in Eugene, to Reuben and Eunice Hinton Maier. She married V.V. "Bud" Kuykendall in 1958. They later divorced. She married Dennis Thompson on June 8, 1972.

She graduated from Eugene High School. Thompson worked for the Eugene Planing Mill and other businesses in Eugene before moving to Bend in 1970. She and her husband started Tomco Electric in 1973. In 1989, she started Design Lighting.

Thompson enjoyed swimming, water skiing, flying, scuba diving, horses, nature, spending time at Crescent Lake and the beach, and spending time with her children and grandchildren.

Thompson was a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and served on its Relief Society and as president of the young women's group. Thompson also served as a seminary teacher and nursery leader. In 1999, she and her husband served a church mission in Salt Lake City.

Survivors include her husband; three daughters, Stacy Ainge, Sandy Kuykendall and Sharyl Ingram; three sons, James Kuykendall and Colby and Kelly Thompson; two brothers, Reuben Maier of Eugene and Lee Maier of Dexter; and 17 grandchildren.

Today's service will be at 11 a.m. at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Bend. Autumn Funerals in Bend is in charge of arrangements.

Memorial contributions may be made to Bend-LaPine Hospice, 1303 Galveston, Bend, OR 97701.

Michael Rogers

SPRINGFIELD - A memorial service will be today, April 20, for Michael Leroy Rogers of Springfield, who died April 13 of complications after surgery. He was 57.

Rogers was born March 5, 1942, in Detroit, Mich., to Ophetta White.

He graduated from high school and served in the Navy for three years. He worked in public service and enjoyed cooking and dogs. He had received honors from several civic organizations.

Survivors include his mother of Detroit; a son, Neal of California; a sister, Verna Carter of Detroit; and two grandchildren.

Today's service will be at 11 a.m. at Andreason's Cremation & Burial Service, 110 S. 34th St. in Springfield.

Horace Nickson

COOS BAY - A memorial service will be today, April 20, for Horace E. "Nick" Nickson of Coos Bay, formerly of Eugene, who died April 4 of kidney failure. He was 72.

Nickson was born Dec. 29, 1929, in Portland to Horace and Evelyn Pitzer Nickson. He married Glenda Wheeler in Pleasant Hill on Sept. 6, 1952.

He grew up in Eugene and graduated from Eugene High School and worked as a driver and as a salesman. Nickson enjoyed sailing, hunting and fishing. He was a member of the Coos Bay Kiwanis and the First United Methodist Church and a life member of the Coos Bay Yacht Club.

Survivors include his wife; three daughters, LoAnne and Lynnae, both of Coos Bay, and Kathie of Georgia; a sister, Ginnie Powell of Sheridan, Wyo.; and seven grandchildren.

Today's service will be at 1 p.m. at First United Methodist Church in Coos Bay. Burial will be at Sunset Memorial Park in Coos Bay. Nelson's Bay Area Mortuary in Coos Bay is in charge of arrangements.

Memorial contributions may be made to the memorial fund at First United Methodist Church in Coos Bay.

Marion Hines

CHESHIRE - Marion B. "Bootsie" Hines of Cheshire died April 13 of an aneurysm. She was 77.

Hines was born Oct. 17, 1924, in Jackson, Miss., to Corwin and Marion Snyder Muse. She married Leonard Curtis "Punch- y" Hines in Clinton, Miss., in December 1942. He died in 1974.

She lived in Clinton until 1962 when she moved to Reedsport. She worked in payroll and accounting in the Reedsport school system from 1964 to 1973.

Hines moved to Eugene in 1974 after her husband died. She worked in payroll for Lane Community College in Eugene from 1975 until 1985, when she retired. In 1995, she moved to Cheshire to live with her daughter.

Hines enjoyed spending time with her family, reading, gardening, music and cats.

Survivors include two daughters, Deb Hines of Cheshire and Jude Hines of Eugene; a brother, Corwin Muse Jr. of Jackson; one grandchild; and three great-grand- children.

No services will be held. Her family will spread her ashes at a later date. Poole-Larsen Funeral Home in Eugene is in charge of arrangements.

Memorial contributions may be made to the Greenhill Humane Society or a charity for children.

W. Michael Swangard

W. Michael Swangard of Vancouver, B.C., formerly of Eugene, died April 11 of age-related causes. He was 98.

Swangard was born Sept. 3, 1903, in Munich, Germany, to Fredrich and Elisabeth Wallner Swangard. He married Helen Mathews in 1936. She died in 2000.

He immigrated from Germany to Canada in 1922 and worked as a farmhand in Saskatchewan. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of Saskatchewan and advanced degrees in biochemistry, public health, veterinary medicine and virology at the universities of British Columbia and Munich.

He served as a medical officer under Chiang Kai-shek from 1932 until 1933 and as an officer in the U.S. Army Intelligence Corps during World War II. He received various academic appointments in London, Boston and Pullman, Wash.

Swangard was a veterinarian in Eugene from 1941 to 1959.

He conducted pharmaceutical research and did administrative work for the laboratories of Diamond, Abbott and Bayer in the United States, Belgium, Germany and Spain, where he lived for 20 years.

He returned to Vancouver in 1985, where he wrote historical novels until his death.

Survivors include two sons, Robert and Michael; two grandchildren; and one great-grandchild.

No service is planned. Vancouver Memorial & Crematory is in charge of arrangements.

Mark Emery

SPRINGFIELD - The funeral will be April 22 for Mark W. Emery of Springfield, who died April 16 of respiratory failure and myotonic dystrophy after being on life support since September 1999. He was 38.

Emery was born Feb. 2, 1964, in Spokane to Lonnie Emery and Carol Peterson Poore.

He lived in Spokane until 1980, when he moved to Hermiston. He graduated from Hermiston High School and moved to Springfield in 1986.

Emery worked in the deli at Lane Community College's downtown center and as a dishwasher at the main campus. He enjoyed bowling, working with wood and playing board games and cards. He was involved with the Special Olympics and enjoyed basketball and track.

Survivors include his father of Pasco, Wash.; his mother and stepfather, Carol and Ed Poore of Springfield; his grandfather, Bill Peterson of Spokane; a brother, Larry of San Francisco; a stepbrother, Dearl Poore of Springfield; two sisters, Nancy Emery of Springfield and Penny Heller of Rockaway Beach; and a stepsister, Brenda Hemminger of Springfield.

Visitation will be from 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. Sunday at Springfield Memorial Funeral Home. Monday's service will be at 11 a.m. at the funeral home. Burial will be at Springfield Memorial Gardens. Memorial contributions may be made to the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

Arno Oberleiter

A memorial service will be April 23 for Arno B. Oberleiter of Eugene, who died April 10 of age-related causes. He was 85.

Oberleiter was born April 19, 1915, in Wisconsin to Leo and Anna Heinle Oberleiter. He married Ruth Behrens in Cedarburg, Wis., in June 1941. She died April 19, 1995.

He graduated from Wartburg Theological Seminary after receiving two master's degrees. He was ordained in 1941 by the Lutheran Church of America and was a hospital administrator in the Los Angeles area from 1971 to 1984.

Oberleiter lived in Ontario, Calif., before moving to Eugene 16 years ago.

His hobbies included writing poetry and playing golf. He was a member of Mensa and past president of the Ya-Po-Ah Terrace Resident Council.

Survivors include three daughters, Karen Franz of Riverside, Calif., Kathleen Oberleiter of San Bernardino, Calif., and Carol Nadelman of Fontana, Calif.; a brother, Carl Oberleiter of Aurora, Colo.; six grand-children; and 10 great-grand- children.

Tuesday's service will be at 4 p.m. at Central Lutheran Church in Eugene. Andreason's Cremation & Burial Service in Eugene is in charge of arrangements.

Memorial contributions may be made to Central Lutheran Church.

Timothy Prom

Timothy E. "Tim" Prom of Glendale, Ariz., died March 29 of heart complications. He was 58.

He was born April 19, 1943, in St. Cloud, Minn., to George and Betty Secord Prom. He lived in Harrisburg and Monroe for 14 years.

Prom owned and operated Algal Fence Co. in Glendale.

Survivors include his wife, Shirley James Prom; four daughters, Dawn Prom of Arkansas, and Rossyln Ray-Bowers, Treva Haggard and Kari Pruet, all of Arizona; three brothers, Duane of Junction City, Veryle of Harrisburg and George of Texas; four sisters, Mary Schoen and Arvella Kokkeler, both of Junction City, and Sandi Hay and Cheryl Whitakker, both of Eugene; and nine grandchildren.

A graveside service was held April 2 at Greenwood Memory Lawn Mortuary and Cemetery in Phoenix. No local services are planned.

Helen Wickman

COTTAGE GROVE - Helen Wickman of Cottage Grove died March 30 of Alzheimer's disease complications. She was 82.

Wickman was born April 5, 1919, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to Oscar and Anna Eklund Peterson. She married Alfred Wickman in Poughkeepsie on Jan. 11, 1942. He died Nov. 26, 1978.

She graduated from high school in Poughkeepsie and received a degree in physical education from Savage School of Physical Education. She lived in Denver from 1955 to 1980 and in San Francisco from 1980 to 1989, when she moved to Cottage Grove.

Wickman enjoyed flying airplanes and playing golf. She was a district captain of the Democratic Party and president of a Toastmistress Club in Denver. In her earlier years, she was president of a branch of the Parent-Teacher Association and a member of the League of Women Voters.

Survivors include two daughters, Patricia Taylor of Kansas City, Mo., and Gretchen Hargreaves of Kettle Falls, Wash.; a son, Peter of Burlingame, Calif.; two sisters, Evelyn Barclay of Newburgh, N.Y., and Mildred Peterson of Wappingers Falls, N.Y.; and seven grand- children.

No services are planned. England's Eugene Memorial Chapel is in charge of arrangements. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

The News Department will accept information on its standard obituary forms submitted through funeral homes or by the deceased's immediate family. Obituary information is available at (phone) 485-1234, Ext. 5534, or (fax) 683-7631.
